docs.lead_paragraph: LANE--Mark. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of Mark Lane, Fidelis Care President and CEO, who passed away unexpectedly on July 22. The tradition of the Catholic health care ministry found a new expression in Fidelis Care, and Mr. Lane guided the health plan to become an advocate, a resource, and an answer for uninsured children and adults of all ages. From the beginning, he expressed and instilled in each of us an uncommon passion for excellence, the highest attention to detail, and a steadfast commitment to the company's mission of serving the poor and most vulnerable with compassion, dignity, and respect. His vision for what Fidelis Care could be was realized not only in the company's growth and success over the years, but also in the lives that were changed by having access to quality, affordable health insurance. He cared about people from all walks of life - children, parents, college students, jobless adults who recently lost health insurance, the low-income elderly, residents of rural areas, and those in New York's largest cities - there was no population too small, no story too insignificant for his focus and attention. With one set of values, Mr. Lane lived life seamlessly. Whether as steward of a successful company, or as loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather, the same uncompromised principles prevailed. We are grateful for his vision and the standards and expectations he established, giving each of us a foundation upon which to build as we go forward, day by day. This is how we will honor him; he will never be forgotten. - The Board and Staff of Fidelis Care New York

headline.main: How Can We Prevent Another Dust Bowl?

docs.abstract: Is the current drought raising the possibility of another Dust Bowl? If so, what can we do to prevent it?
docs.snippet: Is the current drought raising the possibility of another Dust Bowl? If so, what can we do to prevent it?

headline.main: The Agenda: Too Much Medical Care?

docs.abstract: In the latest post from The Agenda series, Tara Parker Pope looks at the rising costs of health care in the United States, and the problems with receiving unnecessary medical services.
docs.snippet: In the latest post from The Agenda series, Tara Parker Pope looks at the rising costs of health care in the United States, and the problems with receiving unnecessary medical services.

docs.abstract: The United States spends an estimated $210 billion annually on unnecessary medical services. For patients, this often means getting pulled into a cycle of repeated lab work, scans and other medical tests.
docs.snippet: The United States spends an estimated $210 billion annually on unnecessary medical services. For patients, this often means getting pulled into a cycle of repeated lab work, scans and other medical tests.

docs.lead_paragraph: A court said higher health and pension contributions amount to a salary reduction, which the State Constitution prohibits for judges.

headline.seo: N.J. Court Says Judges Exempt From Increased Benefit Contributions
headline.main: Court Exempts Judges From New Jersey’s Curbs on Benefits
headline.print_headline: Court Exempts Judges From New Jersey’s Curbs on Benefits

docs.abstract: New Jersey Supreme Court rules that New Jersey judges and justices are constitutionally protected from a new law requiring state employees to contribute more toward their health and retirement benefits; ruling is criticized by Gov Chris Christie, who championed the controversial legislative package that was passed in June 2011, restructuring pension and health benefits for state employees.
docs.snippet: A court said higher health and pension contributions amount to a salary reduction, which the State Constitution prohibits for judges.

docs.lead_paragraph: An office and laboratory building nearing completion in the central business district signals the expansion of Louisville’s biggest new economic sector.

headline.seo: Louisville, Ky., Stakes Future on Care for Elderly
headline.main: Louisville, Ky., Stakes Future on Care for Elderly
headline.print_headline: Louisville, Ky., Stakes Future on Care for Elderly

docs.abstract: Office and laboratory building nearing completion in the central business district of Louisville, Ky, signals the expansion of the area's large new economic sector; 200,000 square-foot building will be the fourth, and largest, in the city's Nucleus Innovation Park, where the focus is on promoting new companies involved in care for older people; Louisville is taking the lead in the area of elder care.
docs.snippet: An office and laboratory building nearing completion in the central business district signals the expansion of Louisville’s biggest new economic sector.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision on President Obama’s health law will probably reduce the number of people who gain insurance, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report.

headline.seo: Medicaid Expansion Ruling Blunts Health Law’s Effect
headline.main: Court’s Ruling May Blunt Reach of the Health Law
headline.print_headline: Court’s Ruling May Blunt Reach of the Health Law

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says Supreme Court decision on Pres Obama’s health care overhaul will likely lead to an increase in the number of uninsured, with 3 million fewer predicted to get insurance out of the 33 million who had been expected to gain coverage; law is also expected to cost the government $84 billion less than previously estimated, a modest reduction.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court decision on President Obama’s health law will probably reduce the number of people who gain insurance, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve Bank of New York faced criticism for missing a multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan Chase, the regulator convened a town hall meeting in May to bolster employee morale. Two months later, the New York Fed staff huddled again, after lawmakers questioned why the regulator had failed to rein in banks that manipulated key interest rates.

headline.main: New York Fed Faces Questions Over Policing Wall St.

docs.abstract: Lawmakers question why the Federal Reserve Bank of New York failed to rein in banks that manipulated key interest rates; fundamental problems still persist despite a revamping of the regulator's approach to overseeing the nation's largest banks; the regional Fed bank is on the front line of financial regulation, with its proximity to Wall Street, but does not have enforcement power like many other regulators. Photos, Chart (M)
